context: Despite periodic repression, the Brotherhood has become <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>one of the most influential<a0_2/> movements<a0_1/><a0_0/> in the Islamic world<b5_0/>, particularly in the Arab world. For many years it was described as <a1_0>"<a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>semi-legal<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/>"<a1_0/> and was the only opposition group in Egypt able to <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b7_0>field candidates<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> during elections. In the Egyptian parliamentary election, 2011–2012, the political parties identified as "Islamist" (the Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice Party, Salafi Al-Nour Party and liberal Islamist Al-Wasat Party) won <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b8_0>75%<a3_2/><a3_1/> of the total seats<b8_0/><a3_0/>. <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><b9_0>Mohamed Morsi<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>, an Islamist democrat of Muslim Brotherhood, was the first democratically elected president of Egypt. He was deposed during the 2013 Egyptian coup d'état.
